content:
So I was trying to install the dev env directly, following instructions here :- https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install-generic-unix-dev.html#on-debian-or-ubuntu-systems
I get the following error all the time:-
`
pasted image
I have tried updating the required packages but didn't help..
@Poornima Haridas Hmmm. libffi-dev, libldap2-dev, libmemcached-dev.
Depending on libffi6, libldap-2.4-2, libsasl2-dev, respectively.
(Please double-check that I've transcribed those package names correctly.)
I updated the packages you mentioned but
@Poornima Haridas Perhaps you misunderstood -- I just wanted to check that I had transcribed the names correctly from the screenshot. Did I?
Oh! Yep you did
Great, thanks! Now that'll make it easier for me to search our issue tracker https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues to see if anyone has mentioned these problems
Cool :)

I'll look through this list https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20libffi-dev

In the meantime: Poornima, have you ever repaired your software sources in Ubuntu?
@Poornima Haridas Open up the "Software Sources" application (click the Ubuntu logo in the upper left corner) and type "Software Sources"

(enter your password to proceed)

Then, choose the Maintenance option, and choose "Fix MergeList problems"

By the way, @Poornima Haridas, have you ever used aptitude or dpkg at the command line? There are some interesting options available

I'm looking at https://askubuntu.com/questions/223237/unable-to-correct-problems-you-have-held-broken-packages and I'm wondering whether, in the past, you have told your operating system to "hold" packages at a particular version number?
I used aptitude just today as a way to get around this problem
also by Software sources do you mean software updates?
@Poornima Haridas No, I mean "Software Sources"
Does that application exist on your machine?
Looks like not
@Poornima Haridas I'm using Linux Mint, which is a derivative of Ubuntu -- perhaps they have different names for things

@Poornima Haridas
Some programmers use a site called Hastebin to paste things (like, long logs and stuff like that). http://hastebin.com/ It's helpful so other people can see what you've already done to try to address a problem. I'd love to use it to see what you have already tried out.

In your console, run the command history -a (this will make sure that your ~/.bash_history file includes the most recent stuff you've typed into the command line).

And then run the command history . Then go to http://hastebin.com in a web browser, and paste the resulting text into the webpage there and click the Save icon on the right, and then tell me the resulting URL.

On Linux, so much debugging information is *text* -- this approach, rather than screenshots, makes it easier for the people helping you to debug stuff, because we can copy and paste text into search engines, use "control-F" to find things, and so on.
Thanks! That's very convenient! :)
http://hastebin.com/geqiqikaga.sql
/me looks
@Poornima Haridas Hmm, starting on line 3, do you see how slashes got introduced into the command you were typing?
yep
@Poornima Haridas if I had to guess, I would say that, instead of using the up arrow in bash to simply repeat what you had invoked before, you copied and pasted in a way that introduced slashes
@Poornima Haridas maybe that is a cause of the prob
sorry, phone call from family, back in a few minutes I hope
/me is back
@Poornima Haridas Have you been able to use this clue to repair things?

nope
I have tried aptitude
removed the extra slashes but the same problem
@Poornima Haridas do you know whether you have ever told aptitude to "hold" packages?
Not that I can recall
@Poornima Haridas I bet there's a way for dpkg or aptitude to tell you, though, so you can know for sure.

I tried dkpg but it doesnt show any packages
as shown in the link you sent
*dpkg
@Poornima Haridas also, could you put the text of /etc/apt/sources.list into a Hastebin, and the text of /etc/apt/preferences into another Hastebin, and paste both links here?
Also @Poornima Haridas just to be super clear and specific: are you saying that you ran dpkg --get-selections | grep hold and it simply returned nothing and you got a new prompt?
Yep
Just did it again
Thanks for clarifying that @Poornima Haridas (more detail about what command you ran and specificity about the output definitely helps me & future helpers help you better)

http://hastebin.com/tawepahalo.nginx
thats sources.list
preferences is empty..
Looking now.

@Poornima Haridas The reason I asked about /etc/apt/preferences is to check whether you had "pinned" anything as referenced in https://help.ubuntu.com/community/PinningHowto . And thanks for the sources.list. Looking now.
Looks like everything in there says trusty which means I should look elsewhere for more clues
/me researches
I hope it's not something very silly...
@Poornima Haridas :) if you look back in the archives of this Zulip realm you will find places where I've made silly mistakes. All will be ok, I bet
@Poornima Haridas so when you try to invoke sudo aptitude install libffi-dev do you get multiple options for how to resolve the dependencies, or just 1 option?
Only 1 option
/me ponders

' Keep the following packages at their current version:
1) libsasl2-dev [Not Installed] `
@Poornima Haridas check out http://askubuntu.com/a/223267 which suggests you try sudo aptitude -f install <packagename>

And when I look at the man page for aptitude I see:

        -f
           Try hard to fix the dependencies of broken packages, even if it means ignoring the actions requested on the command line.

           This corresponds to the configuration item Aptitude::CmdLine::Fix-Broken.

       --full-resolver
           When package dependency problems are encountered, use the default “full” resolver to solve them. Unlike the “safe” resolver activated by --safe-resolver, the full resolver
           will happily remove packages to fulfill dependencies. It can resolve more situations than the safe algorithm, but its solutions are more likely to be undesirable.

           This option can be used to force the use of the full resolver even when Aptitude::Always-Use-Safe-Resolver is true. The safe-upgrade command never uses the full resolver
           and does not accept the --full-resolver option.
So those might be worth trying
/me is learning things as well
I've tried -f. I'll try the other option too.

@Poornima Haridas the next time you get a chance, if you can run history -a and history again and hastebin it and give me the URL, I'd appreciate it. It'll help me understand what you've tried in the past hour and how I can avoid telling you redundant ideas
makes sense :)
http://hastebin.com/qivadokawa.bash
It gives the same 1 option
@Poornima Haridas Hmm, I seem to be missing the history between lines 752 and 762. Are you truncating what you're hastebinning?
http://hastebin.com/citamuseze.sql
sorry was redundant/typo things I tried so didn't include
@Poornima Haridas quick question: if I'm trying to help you fix things, do you think it's more helpful for me to have more or less data about what you've tried, including typos and redundancies? :)
Sorry! Silly of me.. :)

@Poornima Haridas I understand that in a lot of contexts, like if you're talking face-to-face with someone about certain kinds of problems, it's better to leave out what seems like inessential detail.
@Poornima Haridas Learning how to contribute to open source also includes learning about our peculiar modes of communication. It takes some learning! So, no worries. :)

:)
I'm a first timer! No problems. Correct me as much as possible. Here to learn as much as possible :D

If you look at past issues in our issuetracker, or past mail on the main Zulip development mailing list, you'll see that people paste as much of their logs as they can into the issue or mail, because it's fairly easy for the helpers to skim past the details we don't need, but it can be hard for the person needing help to know ahead of time what will turn out to be important versus unimportant
True.. Will keep that in mind :)
Cool. Now: when you ran sudo -H/bin/bash what were you trying to do? and did you realize that you were missing a space after the H?

Also, @Poornima Haridas, if you look at http://askubuntu.com/a/428242 you see that -- when you try running sudo aptitude install <package>, if it gives you a possible solution and you say n for no, it will try to give you another option!
maybe you should try that
Also I just learned of aptitude why-not from https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/121149/fix-held-broken-packages-on-debian
I was trying to change the the directory again in to /etc for which i googled 'a how to' cos the prev one gave error
I later saw that sources.list(a file) was included in the path which was the error
Re-trying with the 'n' option
If you try to sudo a .list file I presume bash doesn't quite understand what to do with it -- you probably meant to invoke an editor like vi

And I'll also mention that https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23035310/ubuntu-unable-to-correct-problems-you-have-held-broken-packages just told me about the remove, clean, and autoclean arguments to apt-get, which are worth your attention as well

Yeah
which i finally did :)
yeah, I see that later in the history :)

When you're typing arguments into bash, it's worth it to slow down and double-check that you have spaces where you mean to have spaces, and you don't have, for instance, extraneous slashes that ought not be there.
so with option 'n' it gives an option of downgrade the libsasl2
will keep in mind to slow down
http://hastebin.com/foyozojami.vbs
should I go for this option?
@Poornima Haridas you know what you could do? just keep saying "n" and seeing what options it's going to give you
@Poornima Haridas and then when it says "I'm sorry Poornima I have no further options to give you!" then you quit
and run that aptitude why-not thing and find out more
Cool
when you're debugging operating system and package stuff, finding out more data in ways that do not modify the existing situation is a very good idea :)
http://hastebin.com/egosefugom.coffeescript
also by the time you (we) figure this out, you and I will both know more about apt :)
so no more solutions
we sure will :)
OK, good to know. What does why-not tell you about each of these 3 problem packages?

aptitude why-not libsasl2-dev
Unable to find a reason to remove libsasl2-dev.
once you're done looking through those why-nots, Poornima, check out https://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/ubuntu-63/how-to-fix-broken-package-904637/ for some more ideas
http://hastebin.com/jaromogido.rb
reading
http://hastebin.com/ilevexoxod.sql
(yay Synaptic!)

http://hastebin.com/sukiqisewa.sql
I saw that a synaptic package manager that I installed to get this result :/
How frustrating!
Maybe some of those suggestions in the linuxquestions.org thread will help

It's like a vicious cycle..
*nervous smiles..
reading the new link :)
you meant the prev linuxquestions.org link you sent right?
Yeah, https://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/ubuntu-63/how-to-fix-broken-package-904637/
I tried the apt-get clean

sent the link
http://hastebin.com/ilevexoxod.sql
/me reads along
clean just gives the prompt again after which i proceed to update and upgrade
@Poornima Haridas and then does the install of the problem packages go any better?
Nope

AAARGH. OK, here's my suggestion. We've been working on this for a couple of hours. By the law of https://blogs.akamai.com/2013/10/you-must-try-and-then-you-must-ask.html I suggest you take 15 minutes to write up an email about what you've tried and then send it to the mailing list https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zulip-outreachy-round-13
And make a few notes to yourself about options to try next
and then do something *else* while you wait for a reply
it could even be something that will help you learn to contribute to Zulip, like reading more of https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

Ok! I'll do that after dinner :)
I should attach the logs right?
Yeah, if you can copy and paste logs, including the errors and responses you got from apt & aptitude and so on, that would be helpful
Cool!
dinner is a good idea :) what are you having?
Dosha :)
I WAS JUST HOPING IT WAS DOSHA
(my parents are from Karnataka so I'm used to Mysore-style)

:D
I love it :)
/me was born and raised in US
Oh nice :)
I'm from kerala but brought around the country...
*brought up
oh I'd love to visit Kerala. I'm really interested in the political history of Kerala in particular
Oh that is quite eventful thanks to the communist party
Have you been anywhere else in India?
Yeah - Delhi and Mumbai, basically
ok, I'm going to follow your lead and eat something -- it's 11:21 here in NYC
talk with you later!
Cool! :)
I'll update after I've written that mail :)
@Poornima Haridas it seems to me like you have a problem with your /etc/apt/sources.list* configuration mixing packages from different versions of debian/ubuntu
In particular you seem to have newer versions of the libfoo library packages than you have the libfoo-dev packages available in your apt repository
@Tim Abbott Ummm.. ok. But I'm not sure what I should do to ensure that sources.list doesnt have mixed versions of ubuntu?
Should I take the option of downgrading the libsasl2?
yeah, that's probably fine

just to be sure
http://hastebin.com/foyozojami.vbs
here I should try 'Y' and see if the downgrading works right?
Should be (gtg AFK for the next several hours)
cool! If that doesnt work I'll send the mail :)

ok so the downgrading does work. but I havent gone beyond the
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:groonga/ppa
on this page
https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install-generic-unix-dev.html#on-debian-or-ubuntu-systems
because next calls for an update. wont that upgrade my packages again? and even if it can be skipped here, won't it cause a problem later when an upgrade is called for and all packages are updated and then upgraded?
Also after the apt-get update are options for version 14.04 and 16.04. My version is currently 15.10. Which one do I choose there?

apt-get update doesn't upgrade your packages. It just updates your package index. You'll need to call apt-get update so that your package index is updated with packages from pgroonga's PPA. If you do sudo apt-get install postgresql-9.5-pgroonga without first calling sudo apt-get update, you'll get an error like 'unable to locate package'.

Do psql --version to find out what version of postgresql you're using. Use that version of pgroonga. For, e.g. on my computer, psql --version outputs psql (PostgreSQL) 9.5.4. So I installed postgresql-9.5-pgroonga.
Cool! I'll try that :)

So i tried as @Eklavya Sharma suggested and it still shows 'unable to locate package'
http://hastebin.com/cohujamilo.sql

AFAIK, the version of postgresql used in Ubuntu 15.10 is 9.4, while you're trying to install postgresql-9.3-pgroonga. Are you sure psql --version showed 9.3?
Launchpad page for postgresql-9.3 (https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/postgresql-9.3) shows that postgresql-9.3 is supported only on Ubuntu 14.04.
Launchpad page for postgresql-9.4 (https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/postgresql-9.4) shows that postgresql-9.4 is supported only on Ubuntu 15.04 and 15.10.
Launchpad page for postgresql-9.5 (https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/postgresql-9.5) shows that postgresql-9.5 is supported only on Ubuntu 16.04 and 16.10.

Hi guys,
I tried to install zulip on my vm(on ubuntu Xenial) and when I tried to run the install script it gave me the error with :

Unable to connect to Upstart: Failed to connect to socket /com/ubuntu/upstart: Connection refused

I installed openssh-server beforehand and I "suspect" it might be the cause... something with the new systemd being the one in Xenial(and not Upstart) anymore...
P.S. If i'm on the wrong thread, sorry. I just tried to post on both google groups(zulip-devel and zulip-help) but my posts didn't show up
Hi, @bachibusuc! Let's go to https://zulip.tabbott.net/#narrow/stream/development.20help .
Sorry, here is good since @bachibusuc has clarified that they are trying to run Zulip in production
and is using https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/prod-install.html
I'm sorry for my mistake.
no problem

@bachibusuc in those instructions, did you see this part? Where it says that the install script

automatically logs a transcript to /var/log/zulip/install.log; please include a copy of that file in any bug reports.
yup
ok so I have to fill in a bug report?
@bachibusuc Right now I'm looking at our existing bug reports to see whether this problem has already been reported
@bachibusuc Let's read through https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/990 together
(I ran a search in https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues for the text of your error, and included closed issues in that search)
yup and I read that too
M. Abbott says somehow that doing do-release-upgrade clears the problem^
I'm not sure. I'm looking at the issue closer.

Some programmers use a site called Hastebin to paste things (like, long logs and stuff like that). http://hastebin.com/ I'd like for you to go to http://hastebin.com in a web browser, and paste the /var/log/zulip/install.log text from your VM into the webpage there and click the Save icon on the right, and then tell me the resulting URL.
@bachibusuc You might or might not have to open a bug report in order to get help with this -- but showing us the log is going to be important so that we can look at it to find clues and help you.
As we work on this we'll figure out, together with you, whether opening a bug report is a good next step.
ok, thank you
I don't have access to my machine right now, I will do that when I go home tonight
@Tim Abbott can you check whether @bachibusuc's post to zulip-devel is caught in a spamfilter or something?

Here I got the confirmation of gmail that the email has been sent :
pasted image
Thanks for that :)
Thank you @Sumana Harihareswara !
@bachibusuc is your Xenial server upgraded from Trusty using do-release-upgrade before you tried installing?

I've seen that cause problems for people where they need to uninstall upstart (which is only used on Trusty, not Xenial) because not all Ubuntu packages handle the upstrart->systemd migration properly if upstrart is still installed
(Also, I confirmed the post was indeed caught in my gmail's spam filters)
@bachibusuc is it still useful to reply to your post?
(Not sure if you've figured out the ALLOWED_HOST and EXTERNAL_HOST pieces)

Hi @Tim Abbott , thanx for taking the time.
I figured it out... I tried many options.. and it worked so I guess I'll use that.
but it was a fresh install from Xenial
so here is the hastebin
at line 1702 specifically : http://hastebin.com/ihejaruhor.pl
now I have the rabbit problem... but it wasn't there yesterday
Just to be clear, I installed a fresh ubuntu Xenial 16.04.
Installed openssh-server, then followed the guidlines in the installation
So I just uninstalled upstart and it worked!
strange...

So I have been trying the installation for quite sometime and the postgresql-9.3-pgroonga causes error and says unable to locate package.
I have ubuntu 15.10 and psql --version shows 9.3.14
http://hastebin.com/balenegaha.css
I tried updating to 16.04 but that was also in vain(in an attempt to maybe get it working with the 9.5 version of psql)
http://hastebin.com/eqenetebud.sql
But the update also keeps aborting sighting network problems and ends up like this
http://hastebin.com/oxecicuvaq.sql
What should I do to successfully install zulip so that I can try and start contribution asap?
Upgrade to Ubuntu 16.04 then follow the instructions in this page setting zulip development environment.
I was trying from this page https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install-generic-unix-dev.html#on-debian-or-ubuntu-systems

I just created a development environment by installing zulip directly on my Ubuntu 16.04, and it is working fine except that I just needed to manually install the package virtualenv using apt, also I had to allow my normal user to run commands as user postqres by adding this line mohsen ALL=(postqres) ALL to a new file inside my /etc/sudoers.d/ directory and you are all done.
Use this it is very short and easy just pay attention to the two issues I reported in my last message here.
I have to go now, if you have any question post them here and I will try to answer them as quickly as possible, nice to meet you.
I'm trying my best to iron out issues faced while upgrading to 16.04. Meanwhile it looks like having a 15.10 will be a problem?
Also http://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install-ubuntu-without-vagrant-dev.html after cloning, I'm not sure what ./tools/provision.py step means?

http://hastebin.com/ewawotebit.sql
More problems when trying to setup vagrant
http://hastebin.com/lapegecuki.sql

./tools/provision.py I think this means to install the python virtual environment and install all dependencies for it, if you have a good broadband internet connection you better use vagrant instead which does not depend on your own operating system.
Is it possible to install directly as instructed https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install-generic-unix-dev.html#on-debian-or-ubuntu-systems without updating to ubuntu 16.04?
Give it a try and report back any issues.

You might have problems using Ubuntu 15.10 because it reached end-of-life in July and thus is no longer supported by Ubuntu. Regardless of whether it works for Zulip, you probably want to upgrade to 16.10
Regardless it looks like these issues are caused by something being awry with the apt/dpkg configuration on the machine.

I have been trying to install dev environment from https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-env-first-time-contributors.html#ubuntu . I have windows 10 laptop with a ubuntu 14.04 trust vagrant box set up . I am just confused as to move ahead with setting up the dev environment inside the vagrant box considering the OS to be ubuntu or should I follow the steps to install via windows 10 ?
The Vagnrat instructions would have you create a 14.04 Ubuntu guest just for Zulip; if that makes sense for you, do that
if you'd rather reuse your existing 14.04 Vagrant guest, you can use the Linux instructions from inside that guest
Thanks @Tim Abbott
Hello, I have followed the exact steps to set up a dev environment on windows and am getting the following error when am trying to start the server.Please help
Capture.JPG
@Diptanshu Jamgade try running the command from /srv/zuliplike ./tools/run-dev.py--interface=''.

@Umair Khan it is still giving a no file exists error. I am referring to https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-env-first-time-contributors.html#step-2-get-zulip-code . I also noticed that as mentioned in the documentation, I am not getting any virtual-environment "(zulip-env)" on ssh into the vagrant box. You can notice that with the help of previous screenshot I provided. Might be the error lies therein ?
@Diptanshu Jamgade, for virtual environment do this source /srv/zulip-venv/bin/activate.
@Umair Khan the virtual environment that needs to be activated does't exist in my case ! in the /srv directory "ls -a" shows only zulip/ directory !
Did you provision the vagrant machine?
or rather did the provisioning complete successfully?
You can re-provision by exiting the VM and running vagrant provision.

@Sumana Harihareswara since you mentioned that you are the expert for vagrant systems, I wanted to ask you a very trivial doubt. In cygwin, whenever i do vagrant up from the clonned git repo, i get few warnings stating that "System couln't find the specified path". Could you tell me the reason for such a warning ?

Hi @Diptanshu Jamgade I'm a little confused. I am very much *not* the expert re: vagrant systems - can you point me to where that got said, so I can correct it?

I'm not on Windows and I've never used Cygwin. Maybe you could try searching for that error on DuckDuckGo or something, and see what others have experienced?
I am sorry might be a reading err !
@Diptanshu Jamgade I know a little bit about cywin/windows vagrant setup, can you sent me a screenshot or copy/paste of the errors?

@Christie Koehler sorry for the late reply ! I was inactive. I have been trying hard to setup the dev-env and I have been able to find hacks(detours) to a large number of errors(which i plan to blog about once I get the dev-env up so that in future people get a hint). At present I am stuck at this particular error

+++ dirname scripts/setup/configure-rabbitmq
++ scripts/setup/../get-django-setting RABBITMQ_USERNAME
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripts/setup/../get-django-setting", line 16, in <module>
    print(getattr(settings, sys.argv[1]))

    self._setup(name)
  File "/srv/zulip-venv-cache/ca82ee7860fca0989e3dd68b65a063d489ddaa6b/zulip-py3-venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/conf/__init__.py", line 44, in _setup
    self._wrapped = Settings(settings_module)
  File "/srv/zulip-venv-cache/ca82ee7860fca0989e3dd68b65a063d489ddaa6b/zulip-py3-venv/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/conf/__init__.py", line 113, in __init__

subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['scripts/setup/configure-rabbitmq']' returned non-zero exit status 1

Rabbitmq-error.JPG
It would be really helpful if someone can help me with this error as I have no clue regarding this. @Tim Abbott @Sumana Harihareswara could you guys please help me out with this or suggest some dev who can ? I have no idea about this error !
I don't know what is causing that error, unfortunately. It looks like django isn't configured properly, but I don't know off hand what would cause that.
